sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying disc
message_1: A circular disc has a radius of 0.2 meters and is carrying a current of 5 amps. What is the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the disc, at a distance of 0.1 meters from the center of the disc?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the circular disc, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a current-carrying circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the disc, and x is the distance from the center of the disc along the axis.

Given values:
I = 5 A
R = 0.2 m
x = 0.1 m

Now, let's plug in the values and calculate the magnetic field:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * (0.2 m)²) / (2 * ((0.2 m)² + (0.1 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) * 5 * 0.04) / (2 * (0.05)^(3/2))

B ≈ 2π × 10^(-7) * 5 * 0.04 / (2 * 0.125)

B ≈ 10π × 10^(-7)

B ≈ 3.14 × 10^(-6) T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the given point is approximately 3.14 × 10^(-6) T (tesla).

As for the direction of the magnetic field, it follows the right-hand rule. If you curl the fingers of your right hand in the direction of the current (counterclockwise when looking at the disc from above), your thumb will point in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will be pointing upward along the axis of the disc.
